Name: Ngajumaya
description: Better name for the language would be Marlpamaya (human language) rather than 'Ngajumaya" (I language) (Doug Marmion, pc)

Name: Ngarlawangga
description: name changed from Ngalawangka per Doug Marmion
glottolog_comment: Per Wikipedia Ngalawongga is an alternative name which in turn is an ElCat for the Glottolog language Yinhawangka.

Name: Gunggari
glottolog_comment: The location of the Glottolog language is a bit of an outlier of the Southern Maric group this language belongs to.

Name: Mbabaram
glottolog_comment: Glottolog location seems to be off: https://github.com/glottolog/glottolog/issues/1142

Name: Yulparija
glottolog_comment: Based on location the dialect Yulparitja of Martu Wangka seems a better match than the language with the exact same name.

Name: Mpalityan
description: Changed from Mpalitjanh

Name: Nunukal
description:
Related to yagara, given by Tindale as the name of the Northern group of Stradbroke Island.

(changed from Nukunul to Nunukal per Bill Pascoe)

Name: Janday
description: Djindewal, Jandai

Name: Ngaduk
description: In Birch's 2006 map, Ngaduk is also shown on the Western side of the river, north of Gonbudj.

Name: Wagaman
glottolog_comment: Not Wageman. According to Wikipedia 'The language of the Wakaman people, Wagaman, is thought by some linguists to be a variant of the mutually intelligible Agwamin and Wamin languages.'

Name: Mirniny
description: Spelling of the language name changed from Mirrniny per Doug Marmion (and back per Sue Hanson).

Name: Yidiny
description: boundaries per Dixon grammar

Name: WathiWathi
description: Wadi wadi (Not to be confused with Wodi Wodi, which is a Yuin-Kuri language)

Name: Emmi
description: also known as Maranunggu

Name: Guynmal
description: See breen 09, 6.6, issues with Tindale vs Roth. name is doubtful, can't find in current sources

Name: Wailwan
description: Treated by Donaldson as the Northern dialect of Ngiyambaa

Name: Dharumbal
description: Distant sister to Mbabaram in BBA 2018

Name: Central Arrernte
glottolog_comment: Wikipedia equates Central and Eastern Arrernte and the location around Alice Springs seems to support this.

Name: Eora
description: spelling per Wafer and Lissarrague

Name: Dungaloo
glottolog_comment: Judging by location this is not the Gureng Gureng dialect Dhungaloo.

Name: Keramin
description: Also Kureinji, Yari-Yari

Name: Ngintait
description: Also Ngindadj, Yuu-Yuu given as a reference name in Wafer and Lissarague)

Name: Peramangk
glottolog_comment: https://aiatsis.gov.au/austlang/language/s5 'Little is known about the Peramangk language'

Name: Ndjebbana
description: also called Gunavidji

Name: Raminyeri
glottolog_comment: According to Wikipedia: 'The Ramindjeri language was a dialect of the Ngarrindjeri language'

Name: Tharrayi
description: tindale's Tedei, per Doug Marmion. Probably the same as Thirrily (Southern Yingkarta?)

Name: Thaagurda
description: Language mentioned in Doug Marmion's honour's thesis; not otherwise attested but seems to be a separate language

Name: Kolakngat
description: Kolakngat

Name: Ngarla
Glottolog_Name: Ngarla on the Ashburton river south of the Hamersley range

Name: Ogh-Alungul
glottolog_comment: https://aiatsis.gov.au/austlang/language/y199 Matched to Glottolog subgroup based on Alpher.

Name: Agu Aloja
glottolog_comment: https://aiatsis.gov.au/austlang/language/Y219 Matched to Glottolog subgroup based on Alpher.

Name: Ogh-Angkula
glottolog_comment: https://aiatsis.gov.au/austlang/language/y197 Matched to Glottolog subgroup based on Alpher.

Name: Uw El
glottolog_comment: https://aiatsis.gov.au/austlang/language/y207 Sommer (1971-1974) collected some data, and he treats it as a dialect of Oykangand Y101 (2007 p.c.)
